sub_title: Assistant Professor in International History, Utrecht University / Visiting Research Fellow, King's College London
summary: I am an Assistant Professor in International History at Utrecht University, and a Visiting Research Fellow at the Department of War Studies, King's College London. I am a historian and a genocide scholar, and my work is on irregular armed groups, genocide and mass violence and transitional justice, especially criminal accountability. Before coming to The Hague in 2009, I spent three years in Sarajevo, where I worked as a researcher and analyst at the Special Department for War Crimes at the Office of the Prosecutor. I designed and taught an MA course on perpetrators and genocide prevention at Stockton University in the United States. My first book titled “Serbian Paramilitaries and the Breakup of Yugoslavia: State Connections and Patterns of Violence” came out in September 2022 with Routledge’s Contemporary Security Studies series. This research was based on archives at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) in The Hague. I am also one of three editors of the new CEU Press series “Perpetrators of Organized Violence: Eastern, Central and South-Eastern Europe”.

awards.description: BIRN has awarded me one of the grants for small projects exploring the archives of the International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia (ICTY) and domestic courts in ex-Yugoslav countries that dealt with war crimes cases.

awards.description: I was awarded best doctoral paper at the ASN Convention in New York (Columbia University, Harriman Institute). The title of my paper was: Paramilitary Violence in the Former Yugoslavia: Insights from War Crimes Trials.

projects.title: Pictures of Peace and Justice Documentation, Evidence and Impact of Visual Material in International War Crimes Prosecution
projects.description:
The project was a pilot study, conducted with colleagues from King's College London War Studies Department, to investigate the importance of visual material vis a vis other types of material at three stages of the process of establishing internationalised judicial processes (i.e. international courts and domestic processes with both significant international input and context).

The first of these was the context in which these judicial bodies are created. The second was the conduct of trials. The third was the impact beyond the courtroom on issues of peace and security.

The project had the goal to (i) identify, document, critically appraise and create data sets of examples of visual evidence at each of the three stages identified; (ii) conduct semi-structured interviews with judicial, policy, media and military-security practitioners to investigate knowledge, understanding and judgement on the relative importance of visual material at each of the three stages; (iii) carry out focus group research to investigate beliefs, values and attitudes regarding particular examples of visual evidence, in light of stages (i) and (ii), including generating processes and cases, use as evidence in trials, and impact on post-conflict societies and communities.

profile_positions.description: I teach several courses in the Department of History, focusing on conflict, mass violence, human rights, transitional justice and international relations. I contribute to the Conflict Studies program, and I'm in charge of supervising MA students as they write their theses.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer

profile_positions.description: I conducted my research within the NWO-funded VIDI project titled 'Paramilitarism, Organized Crime and the State', focusing on Serbia. While doing my PhD at Utrecht University's History Department, I also taught three courses for BA students on genocide and mass violence and led an MA thesis writing lab.
profile_positions.title: PHD Researcher
Visiting Research Fellow at the Department of War Studies

profile_positions.location: Galloway Township, New Jersey, United States
profile_positions.description: I designed and was teaching an online course for MA students called "Perpetrator Behaviour and Genocide Prevention", within the Holocaust & Genocide Studies Program. The course focused on mass violence and genocide in the 20th century, and used research and literature from various disciplines, such as political history, international law, criminology, ethnography, anthropology, social psychology, sociology, political economy, etc.
profile_positions.title: Lecturer

company.name: NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies

profile_positions.company: NIOD Institute for War, Holocaust and Genocide Studies
profile_positions.title: Associate Researcher

profile_positions.description: The main tasks related to identifying, sorting and digitizing a vast amount of archival material produced in the many years Sense News Agency has covered the trials at the International Criminal Tribunal for the former Yugoslavia (ICTY) and other institutions in The Hague. I also managed a large amount of evidence material presented at trials. I worked with researchers, academics, journalists and film makers on their projects on war crimes and war crimes prosecution. I was often asked to brief reporters on developments in trials.
profile_positions.title: Researcher

profile_positions.description: This project funded by the AHRC’s Beyond Text strategic programme investigated the importance of visual material vis a vis other types of material at three stages in relation to internationalised judicial processes (i.e. international courts and domestic processes with both significant international input and context): the context in which these judicial bodies are created; the conduct of trials; and impact beyond the courtroom on issues of peace and security.
profile_positions.title: Researcher

company.name: Office of the Prosecutor, War Crimes Department

profile_positions.company: Special Department for War Crimes, Prosecutor's Office of Bosnia and Herzegovina
profile_positions.description:
I was part of a team that gathered, reviewed and listed all open case files in Bosnia and Herzegovina relating to war crimes. While I was at the Office of the Prosecutor, we reviewed hundreds of case files, listing suspects, victims and witnesses and describing reported incidents. We were populating a database that will enable a different organization and division of labor and will help avoid duplication of efforts. It will also allow better cooperation with other prosecutors in the country and abroad. 

I worked with prosecutors on individual cases (these included charges of genocide, crimes against humanity, war crimes; cases of torture, rape and sexual violence, unlawful detention, beatings). I searched for documents in databases and analyzed them as well as compiled collections of documents relevant to the particular case. Occasionally I worked with legal officers on assembling documents and sorting forensic reports (particularly for Srebrenica) and massive amounts of related information.
profile_positions.title: Analyst and Researcher

profile_positions.description: For the Media Center I wrote about media and justice; coverage of war crimes trials; I wrote book reviews and did event coverage aiming at supporting journalists that covered the judiciary and more broadly, human rights and transitional justice topics. I have also conducted interviews with film makers and activists in the field.
profile_positions.title: Freelance Journalist

profile_positions.description:
I worked as a project manager for the Research and Documentation Centre on a research project with a Swiss NGO called Swisspeace. We worked on a report from Bosnia and Herzegovina (BiH) for a larger project on BiH and Guatemala. The focus was on how communities dealt with the aftermath of genocide, crimes against humanity and war crimes. With a colleague I travelled around BiH, interviewing victims, NGO workers, activists, individuals working on missing persons identification for ICMP, political party representatives and journalists. 

During this time I was also working with XY Films on their TV series about war crimes prosecutions done for crimes committed in BiH and I was hired as a moderator for public discussions in several Bosnian towns. I started working for the RDC while I was pursuing my masters’ degree and continued until I was offered a position at the Special War Crimes Department, not long after I finished my degree. While at the RDC, I worked with NGOs from BiH and the region that were active in the field of victims’ rights, documentation and transitional justice.
profile_positions.title: Project manager

profile_positions.description:
While at Radio 101, I worked on several programs and shows including the daily news program. For about two years I was also the editor of the daily news and the show on civil society and human rights. This was a project in collaboration with the Center for Peace Studies funded by the Academy for Educational Development.

In 2007 I spent a month in the U.S., in Washington D.C, in San Francisco and New Orleans as a fellow of the U.S. Department of State’s Edward R. Murrow Program for Journalists.
profile_positions.title: Journalist and Editor
